description: From Middle English friggen (“to quiver”), perhaps from Old English *frygian (“to rub, caress”), related to Old English frēogan, frīgan (“to love, release, embrace, caress”), frīge (pl., “love”). More at free.
Alternative etymology derives frig (Early Modern English frigge) from Middle English frikien (“to keep (the arms and hands) in constant motion”), from Old English frician (“to dance”).

entries.meaning: A temporary modification to a piece of equipment to change the way it operates (usually away from as originally designed).
examples: I had to put a couple of frigs across the switch relays but it works now.

verbs.description: frig (third-person singular simple present frigs, present participle frigging, simple past and past participle frigged)

examples: She never forgot the day she was caught frigging herself in the library.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive, slang, euphemistic) to fuck; to have sex.
(intransitive, slang) to mess or muck (about, around etc.; cannot be used on its own)
examples: Be sensible; you’re just frigging about now.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive, slang) to make a temporary alteration to something, to fudge, to manipulate
examples: The system wasn't working but I've frigged the data and it's usable now.
